dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeCycle
dataObjects.description: The pelagic-broadcast spawning behavior consisted of males pursuing a single female and nudging her abdominal region. When the female was ready to spawn, a single male wrapped around the female at which time eggs and milt were simultaneously expelled. Reproduction usually consisted of several individual spawning episodes with at least 10-min intervals between events (Ref. 35784).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus
dataObjects.description:
Current Listing Status Summary

Status: Endangered
Date Listed: 07/20/1994
Lead Region:   Southwest Region (Region 2)   
Where Listed: Entire, except where listed as an experimental population

Status: Experimental Population, Non-Essential
Date Listed: 12/08/2008
Lead Region:   Southwest Region (Region 2)   
Where Listed: Rio Grande, from Little Box Canyon to Amistad Dam


Population detail:

Population location: Rio Grande, from Little Box Canyon (approximately 10.4 river miles downstream of Fort Quitman, TX) to Amistad Dam; and on the Pecos River, from its confluence with Independence Creek to its confluence with the Rio Grande.
Listing status: EXPN

Population location: Entire, except where listed as an experimental population
Listing status: E

For most current information and documents related to the conservation status and management of Hybognathus amarus , see its USFWS Species Profile

agents.full_name: US Fish and Wildlife Service - Endangered Species Program

dataObjects.subject: http://www.eol.org/voc/table_of_contents#Taxonomy
dataObjects.description:
Comments: Hybognathus amarus formerly was included in H. nuchalis; it was treated as a distinct species by Hlohowskyj et al. (1989), Sublette et al. (1990), Robins et al. (1991), and some other authors, but was retained as a subspecies of H. nuchalis by Page and Burr (1991). Allozyme data support the hypothesis that H. amarus is a valid taxon, separate from H. nuchalis and H. placitus (Cook et al. 1992). Morphological data also support recognition of Hybognathus amarus as a valid species (Bestgen and Propst 1996). Nelson et al. (2004, AFS list) included H. amarus as a distinct species.

See Schmidt (1994) for a phylogenetic analysis of the genus Hybognathus based on morphological data.
